links.title: Betteridge's law of headlines - Wikipedia
links.description: Betteridge's law of headlines is an adage that states: "Any headline that ends in a question mark can be answered by the word no." It is named after Ian Betteridge, a British technology journalist who wrote about it in 2009,[1][2] although the principle is much older. As with similar "laws" (e.g., Murphy's law), it is intended to be humorous rather than the literal truth.[3]

links.title: Need for Sleep: the Impact of a Night of Sleep Deprivation on Novice Developers' Performance
links.description:
We present a quasi-experiment to investigate whether, and to what extent,
sleep deprivation impacts the performance of novice software developers using
the agile practice of test-first development (TFD). We recruited 45
undergraduates and asked them to tackle a programming task. Among the
participants, 23 agreed to stay awake the night before carrying out the task,
while 22 slept usually. We analyzed the quality (i.e., the functional
correctness)...

Your manager will expect you to work weekends, and your teammates will expect you to reply to b...

links.title: How to say “no” to your boss, your boss’s boss, and even the CEO
links.description: You’ve got plenty of work to do already, when your boss (or their boss, or the CEO) comes by and asks you to do yet another task. If you take yet another task on you’re going to be working long hours, or delivering your code late, and someone is going to be unhappy. You don’t want to say no to your boss (let alone the CEO!). links.title: 996 working hour system - Wikipedia
links.description: The 996 working hour system (Chinese: 996工作制; pinyin: Jiǔjiǔliù gōngzuò zhì), is an overtime work schedule of 9:00 AM–9:00 PM, 6 days per week.[1][2][3][4][5][6][7] A number of Mainland China internet companies have declared this as their official work schedule,[8] despite the fact that the Labour Law of the People's Republic of China states that labourers shall work for no more than eight hours a day and no more than 44 hours a week on average; ...

links.title: Law of truly large numbers - Wikipedia
links.description: The law of truly large numbers (a statistical adage), attributed to Persi Diaconis and Frederick Mosteller, states that with a large enough number of samples, any outrageous thing is likely to be observed.[1] Because we never find it notable when likely events occur, we highlight unlikely events and notice them more. The law seeks to debunk one element of supposed supernatural phenomenology. It is meant to make a statement about probabilities.

links.title: Multiple comparisons problem - Wikipedia
links.description: In statistics, the multiple comparisons, multiplicity or multiple testing problem occurs when one considers a set of statistical inferences simultaneously[1] or infers a subset of parameters selected based on the observed values.[2] In certain fields it is known as the look-elsewhere effect.

links.title: Should you get excited by your data? Let the Look-Elsewhere Effect decide | CMS Experiment

St. Mark's Bookshop was an independent book store, established in 1977 in New York City's East Village neighborhood.  It was the oldest independent bookstore in Manhattan owned by its original owners.
